mcqs.question: Is CSS case-sensitive?
options: Only for class and ID selectors
mcqs.explanation: CSS property names and keywords are case-insensitive, but class and ID selectors are case-sensitive, unless otherwise specified.

mcqs.question: Which of the following selectors is different from `.Menu`?
mcqs.explanation: Class selectors are case-sensitive in most browsers, so `.menu` is different from `.Menu`.

mcqs.question: Which CSS property values are case-insensitive?
mcqs.explanation: Property names and keywords (such as `color`, `font-weight`, `bold`, etc.) are case-insensitive.

mcqs.question: What will happen if you write `COLOR: RED;` instead of `color: red;`?
options: It will work, because CSS properties are case-insensitive
It will only work in some browsers
mcqs.explanation: CSS property names are case-insensitive, so `COLOR` is treated the same as `color`.

mcqs.question: How does HTML’s case sensitivity affect CSS selectors?
options: HTML is case-insensitive, so CSS selectors are always case-insensitive
HTML is case-insensitive, but CSS class and ID selectors are case-sensitive
HTML tags must always be lowercase in CSS
HTML’s case sensitivity has no effect on CSS
mcqs.explanation: HTML is case-insensitive, but CSS selectors for classes and IDs are case-sensitive by default.

mcqs.question: Which selector matches `<div id="Header">`?
mcqs.explanation: ID selectors are case-sensitive in CSS, so only `#Header` matches `<div id="Header">`.

mcqs.question: Which of the following statements is TRUE about CSS selectors and case sensitivity?
options: Class and ID selectors are always case-insensitive
Class and ID selectors are case-sensitive
mcqs.explanation: Type selectors are case-insensitive, but class and ID selectors are case-sensitive.

mcqs.question: If you have `<div class="MyClass">`, which selector will apply styles to it?
mcqs.explanation: Class selectors are case-sensitive, so only `.MyClass` matches `<div class="MyClass">`.

mcqs.question: How can you make an attribute selector case-insensitive?
mcqs.explanation: Use `[attribute=value i]` to make an attribute selector case-insensitive.

mcqs.question: Which of the following is a valid case-insensitive attribute selector?
mcqs.explanation: The `i` after the value makes the selector case-insensitive: `[type="email" i]`.

mcqs.question: What is the default case sensitivity for CSS selectors in XML documents?
mcqs.explanation: Selectors are case-sensitive in XML documents.

mcqs.question: Which CSS property is case-sensitive for its value?
mcqs.explanation: Font family names can be case-sensitive, especially when referring to custom fonts.

mcqs.question: If you define a class `buttonPrimary`, which selector correctly targets it?
mcqs.explanation: CSS class selectors are case-sensitive, so `.buttonPrimary` targets `class="buttonPrimary"`.

mcqs.question: Which of the following will NOT match `<span ID="main">`?
mcqs.explanation: Since `ID` is `main`, only `#main` matches it; `#Main` does not.

mcqs.question: Which is a best practice regarding case-sensitivity in CSS?
options: Always match the exact case of class/ID names
Use camelCase for all CSS properties
CSS does not care about case
mcqs.explanation: Matching the exact case for class and ID names avoids bugs related to case-sensitivity in CSS.
